misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the array will always contain at least one element, meaning index n-1 will always be a valid, non-negative memory address.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to account for the boundary case where N=0. In the Java execution model, an array can have a length of 0, but any attempt to access an index (including n-1) will result in a runtime exception. The student assumes the 'highest score' logic is applicable even when the dataset is empty.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the Scanner's reading methods are functionally partitioned by the System.out.print prompts. They assume that tokens read in the first loop can only come from input provided after the 'Enter names' prompt and before the 'Enter scores' prompt.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student doesn't fully realize that the Scanner reads from a single, continuous input stream (System.in). The prompts (print statements) do not clear or partition the buffer. If a user provides both names and scores in a single block of text, the Scanner will continue to pull tokens sequentially regardless of which prompt was last displayed.
